snippet.textDisplay:
Players too dumb to counter. Any hero can be an extreme pain if left uncountered and uncontested. . .
All I play is competitive. This sounds terrible.
Wasn't this game built on using / thinking of every hero in the deck? That's what kept it exciting.
If you're going to start taking characters away I feel you need to make sure each class has a few redundancies ( much more heros). . .
2-2-2 forcing and now this. . I doubt I'll be playing much more. The limited map pool has already become a slog.

snippet.textDisplay:
In my opinion, hero pool is the worst move you could do for the game's sake at this point. The game doesn't have enough heroes to bring such restrictions, this is just horrible and I see it as the reason me and all of my friends would quit overwatch. Because all of us love to play certain heroes,not just whatever and this is not gonna change if you force us into playing something else, we will just end up not having fun and not playing at all as a result. For example around all 8 tanks I only enjoy playing Dva and I will simply Not play tanks without her available, because all other tanks are not my type. it wouldn't be much of a problem if game had a choice of 30 different tanks, I'm sure there would be around 5 heroes I can swap between...
In other words, hero pool is a really bad, no, worst decision at the current level of hero variety and it's gonna ruin everything.....
snippet.textOriginal:
In my opinion, hero pool is the worst move you could do for the game's sake at this point. The game doesn't have enough heroes to bring such restrictions, this is just horrible and I see it as the reason me and all of my friends would quit overwatch. Because all of us love to play certain heroes,not just whatever and this is not gonna change if you force us into playing something else, we will just end up not having fun and not playing at all as a result. For example around all 8 tanks I only enjoy playing Dva and I will simply Not play tanks without her available, because all other tanks are not my type. it wouldn't be much of a problem if game had a choice of 30 different tanks, I'm sure there would be around 5 heroes I can swap between...
In other words, hero pool is a really bad, no, worst decision at the current level of hero variety and it's gonna ruin everything.....

snippet.textDisplay: So much negativity in the comment section.. I want to be a bit more positive here..I just want to thanks Blizzard and Daddy Jeff for their passion in making Overwatch a fun, competitive, interesting game. After 4 years passed I'm still playing this game from time to time. I think the hero balance issue in Overwatch currently is just fine, maybe there is `unbalanced' thing, but I think we should know the way to counter it. Patches are coming to balance the hero. Play game for fun, not for rage.

snippet.textDisplay: man i hate jeff

snippet.textDisplay:
"We were a bit slow in terms of changes."
Slow? I don't think thats the right word.
Overwhelmed or clueless would fit better.
You literally had to ban 3/3 because you were unable to balance brig in the context she was played in. It was a catastrophe.

Don't misunderstand me, I don't think brig herself was that op (apart from her shield hp, that thankfully got nerfed enough) but her kit in combination with the others is just unbalanceable. You bring stuff into the game that you yourself don't know how to deal with and you even have the nerve to do things as implementing 2/2/2 even though you said you were never going to do that in the past which is hipocrisy at it's finest. Literally shitting on the community's voice unless you break your own game to the point it's inevitable to neglect that one feature any further.

I like the game (with some little exceptions, like hating braindead designs like moira) but I often have to facepalm when I see what blizz is planning to do/doing on PTR and even on live and I don't think the whole situiation is going to change, especially now that you're basically neglecting the base game to create your (most likely) full priced DLC.
snippet.textOriginal:
"We were a bit slow in terms of changes."
Slow? I don't think thats the right word.
Overwhelmed or clueless would fit better.
You literally had to ban 3/3 because you were unable to balance brig in the context she was played in. It was a catastrophe.

Don't misunderstand me, I don't think brig herself was that op (apart from her shield hp, that thankfully got nerfed enough) but her kit in combination with the others is just unbalanceable. You bring stuff into the game that you yourself don't know how to deal with and you even have the nerve to do things as implementing 2/2/2 even though you said you were never going to do that in the past which is hipocrisy at it's finest. Literally shitting on the community's voice unless you break your own game to the point it's inevitable to neglect that one feature any further.

I like the game (with some little exceptions, like hating braindead designs like moira) but I often have to facepalm when I see what blizz is planning to do/doing on PTR and even on live and I don't think the whole situiation is going to change, especially now that you're basically neglecting the base game to create your (most likely) full priced DLC.

snippet.textDisplay: Hero pools sound like a terrible idea... and making balance changes to mess with the meta and undo it a week later sounds like an awful thing too, that's just a "hey we can't actually figure out how to balance the game". There are plenty of alternative decent ideas, like choosing your heroes before the round starts + maybe 1-2 extras you can swap to (or even each team gets 1/2 possible), similar to League/DOTA. Maybe stop trying to make all heroes usable in all situations and go back to having some characters specifically good situationally (ex. Torb)?
snippet.textOriginal: Hero pools sound like a terrible idea... and making balance changes to mess with the meta and undo it a week later sounds like an awful thing too, that's just a "hey we can't actually figure out how to balance the game". There are plenty of alternative decent ideas, like choosing your heroes before the round starts + maybe 1-2 extras you can swap to (or even each team gets 1/2 possible), similar to League/DOTA. Maybe stop trying to make all heroes usable in all situations and go back to having some characters specifically good situationally (ex. Torb)?

snippet.textDisplay: These are good changes. I think that the hero gallery should also have an option to display exact numbers for every ability, and with every patch it shows how they've changed (like the What's New button). The simple descriptions you give in-game are too vague, plain and simple.

snippet.textDisplay:
With the primary goal of hero pools being to influence the meta in a more direct manner, the design as laid out in this video will influence player-specific patterns more than hero-specific patterns. That's neither here nor there really, it's a minor distinction in my estimation, but I suggest some form of "ban pick" or "draft ban" systems that are typically used for ladders in MOBA's. Overwatch acts and feels more like a traditional MOBA than a team-based FPS, but that's just semantics. Ban pick or draft ban systems benefit from being player driven, directly influenced by the players in that match, and change every match. This would let the different ranks in comp decide for themselves, their brackets, what to exclude. There are multiple ways of doing it quasi-fairly but the main reasons such a system is more ideal than hero pools is increased player control and increased hero ban fluidity. As long as there are multiple heroes players want to ban at the same time then forcing them to pick between them for the match will prevent the same hero from being banned in virtually every game. I guess you could call such a thing "ban meta" and there are innumerable ways to tweak such a system for optimal balance and fairness. The hero pools idea is just the map pools concept repackaged. Map pools work great for maps, I honestly think a ban pick, draft ban, or something similar will work far better. Players will always want to ban Mei and Doomfist in their current states, as an example, so it won't be the same hero banned every game virtually 100% of the time UNLESS a hero is so badly broken that such a thing occurring is not only justifiable but actually desired by the community. Even then, that can be fixed with the next balance patch. The only hero I'm concerned about with this kind of hero ban system is Mercy. The community has and always will have to really and seriously contend with a hero who can resurrect a fallen teammate and with good reason. I will say this, though, I believe mercy is in a pretty good spot where she is though tweaking her healing values among other things from time to time wouldn't hurt. I'm well aware my opinion on her balance can be ridiculously different or even contrary to the community's consensus though.

Just what I was thinking. ^_^
snippet.textOriginal:
With the primary goal of hero pools being to influence the meta in a more direct manner, the design as laid out in this video will influence player-specific patterns more than hero-specific patterns. That's neither here nor there really, it's a minor distinction in my estimation, but I suggest some form of "ban pick" or "draft ban" systems that are typically used for ladders in MOBA's. Overwatch acts and feels more like a traditional MOBA than a team-based FPS, but that's just semantics. Ban pick or draft ban systems benefit from being player driven, directly influenced by the players in that match, and change every match. This would let the different ranks in comp decide for themselves, their brackets, what to exclude. There are multiple ways of doing it quasi-fairly but the main reasons such a system is more ideal than hero pools is increased player control and increased hero ban fluidity. As long as there are multiple heroes players want to ban at the same time then forcing them to pick between them for the match will prevent the same hero from being banned in virtually every game. I guess you could call such a thing "ban meta" and there are innumerable ways to tweak such a system for optimal balance and fairness. The hero pools idea is just the map pools concept repackaged. Map pools work great for maps, I honestly think a ban pick, draft ban, or something similar will work far better. Players will always want to ban Mei and Doomfist in their current states, as an example, so it won't be the same hero banned every game virtually 100% of the time UNLESS a hero is so badly broken that such a thing occurring is not only justifiable but actually desired by the community. Even then, that can be fixed with the next balance patch. The only hero I'm concerned about with this kind of hero ban system is Mercy. The community has and always will have to really and seriously contend with a hero who can resurrect a fallen teammate and with good reason. I will say this, though, I believe mercy is in a pretty good spot where she is though tweaking her healing values among other things from time to time wouldn't hurt. I'm well aware my opinion on her balance can be ridiculously different or even contrary to the community's consensus though.

Just what I was thinking. ^_^

snippet.textDisplay:
This makes me sad, players want less dramatic changes. not to see them frequently.
the thing people wanted was for characters to be balanced closer to their launch.
this way the character is not super strong and then NERFd to become super weak.
you need to encourage players to experiment and not get stuck in a stale meta,
but changing things from season to season just because something felt right, will lead to a mess down the road where everything feels NERFd and bad to play.
the biggest thing Overwatch team at blizzard needs to do, is analyze your feedback and where it comes from more accurately.
and a huge thing i think we should all do, is go back and look at the training room..
im not saying change it, but to look at it. its so streamlined and simple, highly intuitive to use that entire little map to practice loads of strategies. and far too many times do we all forget, the complexity of enjoyment from experimentation with rather simple ideas.

you might create a training room 2.0 but its a shame how much is already there, and that most dont realize it.
take each character in and goof around trying to practice something, you can get a good feel on if the character would be viable or not, for the exception of incoming damage, poor tanks. healing or damage output is pretty easy to test tho.
the experimental cards sound like a good idea,
but not the dramatic buff nerfing more frequently. no to that part.
its asymmetrical design which is great, not everything has to be cookie cutter samey.
but its also supposed to be regulated for the standards of an "esport"
thus it really needs to find a nice balance so that several strats are viable and NOT A MONTHLY META ROTATION.
Cause rotating out the meta each month is still a STUPID META.
please dont treat the audience like idiots thank you.

Cause rotating out the meta each month is still a  STUPID META.
please dont treat the audience like idiots thank you.

snippet.textDisplay:
Jeff,

Instead of attacking the meta aggressively you should acknowledge the different metas and force them to happen. Create a set of balanced hero stats for a dive meta, another for a bunker meta, etc. Then just announce what meta will happen. Players will log on and see "Bunker Meta" on the screen and know, "Orissa will have 450 hp right now". This lets you be in control of how your game will be presented to the community instead of making superfluous buffs and nerfs to heros ad nauseam. Why am I going to put time into learning a hero if I know a random buff could come out of nowhere and change everything that I've practiced? At least with forced meta's I can develop a few different play styles to fall back on. (Btw this would force a pseudo-natural hero pool instead of limiting the selection of your player base. Two birds with one stone if you ask me)

Experimental card is bae and a right call. Nice job.
snippet.textOriginal:

This lets you be in control of how your game will be presented to the community instead of making superfluous buffs and nerfs to heros ad nauseam. Why am I going to put time into learning a hero if I know a random buff could come out of nowhere and change everything that I've practiced? At least with forced meta's I can develop a few different play styles to fall back on. (Btw this would force a pseudo-natural hero pool instead of limiting the selection of your player base. Two birds with one stone if you ask me) 

Experimental card is bae and a right call. Nice job.

snippet.textDisplay:
Some small requests with the constant patches:
-Every patch, show the stats for each character on the previous patch and on the PTR (Average overall healing, deaths, damage, kills, etc.)
-Add a tab on the main menu of the game showing the latest patch notes (I don't mean something where you click it and it opens a new tab, more like how the tab works for new items in events, where you just click it and there's all the changes)
-Make golden guns purchasable with Credits (This is to discourage casual players from playing comp and not trying as hard as they could. To keep golden guns rare maybe put a cooldown on purchasing them with credits, like 1 a month or something, but allow comp points to buy them whenever) and also add more weapon specific skins (to add more rewards for playing the game over a long stretch of time)
-Add a new gamemode alongside competitive which uses competitive rules and the next week's hero pool. That way people can start practicing on compositions with that pool with at least a week in advance
-Allow people to set preferred maps within the preexisting competitive map pool (Similar to CS:GO)
snippet.textOriginal:
Some small requests with the constant patches:
-Every patch, show the stats for each character on the previous patch and on the PTR (Average overall healing, deaths, damage, kills, etc.)
-Add a tab on the main menu of the game showing the latest patch notes (I don't mean something where you click it and it opens a new tab, more like how the tab works for new items in events, where you just click it and there's all the changes)
-Make golden guns purchasable with Credits (This is to discourage casual players from playing comp and not trying as hard as they could. To keep golden guns rare maybe put a cooldown on purchasing them with credits, like 1 a month or something, but allow comp points to buy them whenever) and also add more weapon specific skins (to add more rewards for playing the game over a long stretch of time)
-Add a new gamemode alongside competitive which uses competitive rules and the *next week's* hero pool. That way people can start practicing on compositions with that pool with at least a week in advance
-Allow people to set preferred maps within the preexisting competitive map pool (Similar to CS:GO)

snippet.textDisplay: So who's going to get butchered this time? Gonna change another character so they are completely broken or almost useless? "Hero Pooling" is an excessive way of trying to force people to actually become versatile with more than the same 3 characters. I play on Xbox and Playstation and the biggest issues are in bad team composition and players not having a team mentality. If you want to actually make a change that would define matches and gameplay, create a hard character lock that forces every team to have 1 of each class and return the Defence classes to their own category. Most games are lost because there is no healer or a Widowmaker, or any sniper styled mains being awful and waiting to use ults.
snippet.textOriginal: So who's going to get butchered this time? Gonna change another character so they are completely broken or almost useless? I play on Xbox and Playstation and the biggest issues are in bad team composition and players not having a team mentality. If you want to actually make a change that would define matches and gameplay, create a hard character lock that forces every team to have 1 of each class and return the Defence classes to their own category. Most games are lost because there is no healer or a Widowmaker, or any sniper styled mains being awful and waiting to use ults.

snippet.textDisplay: when are we getting new heroes/maps? last hero we got was sigma 6 whole months ago and i can’t remember the last time we got a new map. i think that’s what the overwatch community has been wanting for ages and we’ve not been listened to. overwatch has kinda burned out for me now that there’s nothing new. there should still be new content being added despite the release of overwatch 2 which is when exactly?

snippet.textDisplay: Hero pools ruins the game for me. Now When I think of a counter for something, I need to have the hero pool memorized and sometimes the best hero for the situation or the hero I like to play will not be available. This is lazy balancing tactics by lazy developers.
snippet.textOriginal: Hero pools ruins the game for me. Now When I think of a counter for something, I need to have the hero pool memorized and sometimes the best hero for the situation or the hero I like to play will not be available. This is lazy balancing tactics by lazy developers.

snippet.textDisplay:
Could we go back to less frequent ultimates to and make them tougher to pull off? Or just let suicide tires and high noons kill you before you're able to react to them until the wait times for dps continue to increase?

God forbid tanks and healers be able to respond to them like they used to be able to in ages of older OW before mobility and power creep dominated counterplay and coordinated ultimates.
snippet.textOriginal:
Could we go back to less frequent ultimates to and make them tougher to pull off? Or just let suicide tires and high noons kill you before you're able to react to them until the wait times for dps continue to increase? 

God forbid tanks and healers be able to respond to them like they used to be able to in ages of older OW before mobility and power creep dominated counterplay and coordinated ultimates.

snippet.textDisplay: Hero pools may work for DPS but there are way too few Supports and Tanks for this to be viable.
